Award.AwardTitle: Paleoecosystems of Subarctic Seas (PESAS) Working Group
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support the travel and lodging of participants in the Paleoecology of Subarctic Seas (PESAS) working group to attend the Ecosystem Studies of Subarctic Seas (ESSAS) Annual Science Meeting in Copenhagen, Denmark, April 7-10, 2014. This working group will present research syntheses related to the paleoclimateology, paleoceanography, paleoecology, archaeology, and history of the subarctic North Pacific and North Atlantic. This group will then meet for two days at the end of the conference to work out the logistics, themes, and intellectual responsibilities for preparing a collaborative synthesis volume on the Paleoecology of the Subarctic North Pacific and North Atlantic Seas by 2017. Funds are requested to support the international travel and per diem of 13 participants, including five students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF grant titled "Paleoecosystems of Subarctic Seas (PESAS) Working Group" was provided to support travel of scientists to participate in the inaugural meeting of the PESAS worksing group at the annual meeting of the Ecosystem Studies of Subarctic Seas (ESSAS) regional program. The purpose of the working group is to explore the linkages between atmopheric science, oceanography, marine ecology and human maritime livelihoods over deep time (the past 20,000 years) and across the large regions of the subarctic North Pacific and North Atlantic.The PI and collaborators attended the 2014 ESSAS meeting in Copenhagen, where the working group spent most of two days exploring the relevance of different disciplinary data sets to address questions about the dynamics of ecological regime shifts and human wellbeing in connection to dynamic changes in climate patterns and ocean circulation. Some difficulties in coordinating travel schedules meant that some participants were not able to attend the Copenhagen meeting. Fortunately we were able to repurpose the unused funds through a No Cost Extension to support participation in the second PESAS working group meeting in June 2015, in Seattle (hosted by UW and co-organized by the PI).

Intellectual merits of the project relate to collaborative opportunities to better understand ecodynamically linked systems operating over long scales of time and and large geographic space. The synthesis work of the PESAS groups is directed to better understand the interconnections of atmospherics, oceanography, marine ecosystems, and human economies.  The team is asking how these linkages may have varied from the Deglacial period (18,000 to 10,000 years before present [BP]), 2, the early to late Holocene (ca. 9000 to 3000 BP), 3) the late Holocene (3000-500 BP), and, 4) the growth of subarctic commercial fisheries (500 BP-present). Within these temporal windows, we seek to understand aspects of system resilience and vulnerability to different kinds of shocks from linked systems. 

Broader impacts include the growth of skills in interdisciplinary collaboration (even at the senior level), educating the next generation of interdisciplinary scholars, and potentially the discovery of long term relationships that will challenge recieved wisdom about fisheries resource management, the sustainability of traditional lifeways, and the potential outcomes of more extreme environmental and social changes than we have witnessed in the past few centuries of written and instrumental measurement.

Outcomes:  As a workshop proposal, the expected results within the life of the award are naturally measured in workshop participation and outcomes of the working sessions. In the two funded workshops (Copenhagen 2014 and Seattle 2015), seventeen presentations were made with a combined total of 73 authors covering fields ranging from paleoclimate modeling to chemical oceanography to isotope biogeochemistry to zooarchaeology and human paleodemography. Working group meetings themselves produced surprising insights through comparison of data sets and discussion of linking mechanisms. The project has two ultimate goals: producing at least one synthesis volume in the next few years and creating a self-perpetuating research network to continue to develop the interdisciplinary science of subarctic, long term, human-marine system ecodyamics. Both goals are progressing well and the working group is scheduled to convene again in June 2017 in Tromso, Norway to make the next big step towards the first goal.  Every time we meet we are advancing the second!
